/COMMIT_MSG.message: Isn't pytest actually more analogue to stestr?

pytest is primarly a test framework that hapens to have a test run built in.

so not really.
it combines the functinaly of stestr (via the test runner), unittests (via the testing framework)

pytest can run test written with standard unittest module so you can take nova for example and use pytest to execute its unit test instead of stestr but pytest when used a a libary allow you to do
def test():
  data = {}
  assert type(data) == type(dict())

and it will use pythons built in ast parser to inspect the assertion and generate good error messages.

so unlike unittest2 you dont have to use an learn a bunch of 
self.asertEqual(expected,actual) functions
you just write pythone asserts and if the assert fires because the assetion fails it catches the exception and tells you why.

the plugin design make it easy to integrate with custom testing fixtures which is what pytest-django does
https://pytest-django.readthedocs.io/en/latest/

and pytest-html basically does what our gate sript does and produces a html report of the test resulsts 
https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/122800/11951695/f371b926-a88a-11e5-91c2-499166776bd3.png

openstack/python-openstackclient/python-.message:
so now we'r ein a chicken and egg situation - the individual service clients still require py2+py3 packages, however with the removal of the update-alternatives we're causing a fileconflict between "old py2 openstackclient" and "new py3 only openstackclient". 

can we maybe postpone the removal of the update alternatives? then we should be able to merge this incrementally.
So you're basically proposing to keep the %python_clone and %python_*alternative parts? I'm fine with it, we can always prepare a follow-up patch removing all that.
Same question here as for the barbican-client package: why do you need two separate packages, python-openstackclient and python3-openstackclient ?

Actually, if you check the generated artifacts, there is no python-openstackclient binary rpm, only python3-openstackclient.

The reason to keep python-openstackclient as the "base" name in the spec is to keep consistency with the Python packaging. 

All packages are named after their PyPi name, python-openstackclient in this case. To distinguish Python 3 modules from Python 2 ones (which used to carry the python-* names), they are always named python3-*.

If we created a python3-openstackclient.spec, we'd be breaking the same name rule, and if we just deployed python3 bits using python-openstackclient as the name, we'd be creating a lot of confusion, since it would not be clear which python version is targeted.

specs/approved/L3-based-deployment.rst.message: Can you add a link in references for this redfish capability?

I think it's not about Redfish per se. This paragraph talks about previous reincarnation of this spec (see commit f8816d0b3cad50ced8badd1dd5f8ac7d5f600bd7) which offers slightly different design. From redfish perspective it still boots an image, possibly having floppy disk image inserted at the same time.

It would be ironic conductor, which would be building ISO images per node with IP information? If so I still have the following questions:

1. We should be generating N-number of IPA ISO images. Where N=number of baremetal nodes to be provisioned. Would it scale with higher number of nodes, as it may put challenges on the Disk space.
2. Embedding IP information on Kernel command line:- Do you see any issues hitting 
max limit of "COMMAND_LINE_SIZE", https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/v4.14/admin-guide/kernel-parameters.html with complex network configurations?
3. Redfish does not have a unified VirtualMedia management Interface (Insert/Eject) for all Hardware. It is OEM specific. Does this mean, we should be having Hardware specific Redfish interfaces drivers to handle these cases?

> It would be ironic conductor, which would be building ISO images per node with IP information? If so I still have the following questions:

Yes, that's what's being proposed here. 

> 1. We should be generating N-number of IPA ISO images. Where N=number of baremetal nodes to be provisioned. Would it scale with higher number of nodes, as it may put challenges on the Disk space.

Well, yes. However, the images are built on the conductor machine and then pushed to Swift where they reside for a relatively short time (while node is booting).

Also note, that this spec *adds* floppy-less boot feature which allows us to boot generic user images. Floppy-based configuration is still possible (and it's largely implemented).

> 2. Embedding IP information on Kernel command line:- Do you see any issues hitting max limit of "COMMAND_LINE_SIZE", https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/v4.14/admin-guide/kernel-parameters.html with complex network configurations?

We seem to be guaranteed at least 256 bytes... That probably translates to 4-5 network interfaces... If it's 4096, then it should be around 60 interfaces. So, there is a limit indeed. Does it feel like a pressing thing?

> 3. Redfish does not have a unified VirtualMedia management Interface (Insert/Eject) for all Hardware. It is OEM specific. Does this mean, we should be having Hardware specific Redfish interfaces drivers to handle these cases?

I think virtual media boot can (and should) be done fully in non-OEM way. Everything is in the standard schema.

I have a dream, that (1) all hardware vendors will converge on standard Redfish virtual media boot for basic booting. They still can have OEM for everything on top of just normal, simple machine boot. Secondly, I hope that the vendors would re/base their Redfish ironic drivers on top of generic Redfish driver in ironic.

Am I a dreamer?
This seems to be a useful context, I don't know why it's removed in the revision.
Done
I'd keep it, but it should go to problem description.
This was a useful properly of the approved format. I'd prefer we keep it.
OK, though that would require virtual floppy or USB. That arguably makes the whole thing more demanding and fragile.
Why is it redfish specific? Cannot we do the same for all virtual media?
We can, but that requires refactoring vendor hw types... I wish this is what vendors would do.
do we actually use nfsroot or just reference the kernel argument stuff here?
Just kernel arguments! NFS is just the feature that happens to require the same thing as we need.

How do one get this value? Is this we get from OS using 'ifconfig'? The OS representation of NIC interface differs across distro. Would it be better to pass this as a MAC address? Ironic is also aware of the MAC address.

this seems to be an issue, there is barely a host has only one interface. If we will build a custom ISO, is there a way to embed the network configuration into it?

Is is possible to create a partition and utilize cloud-init for the post-configuration?

It would, however in [1] I do not see a way to pass MAC address...

Also, note, that this `.42` is meant to refer to a VLAN interface. So the assumption here is that the kernel has VLAN networking and interfaces pre-configured through ramdisk configuration before kernel tries to apply its command-line configuration...

BTW, If there is only one interface on the host, then `device` can be omitted.

> this seems to be an issue, there is barely a host has only one interface. 

Sorry, I am not sure I understand your concern. The host can indeed have many interfaces and kernel would configure them though c/l.

> If we will build a custom ISO, is there a way to embed the network configuration into it?

Perhaps, yes. But devil is in details. There should be some standardization concerning network configuration between ironic (injecting configuration into the image) and user init scripts (consuming that configuration). May be something like that already exists? My understanding is that presently os-net-config utilizes floppy drive, but may be it could be turned into some configuration partition...?

In that light, kernel params seem way easier...

WDYT?
I think iLO driver also should move towards non-Floppy based approach.

Well, the necessary harness is almost in place.

The other thought raised in this patch is that if one needs a massive configuration touching ~5+ network interfaces, then perhaps this kernel command-line approach would hit its limit. Then floppy way would be helpful as a fallback option.

specs/approved/L3-based-deployment.rst.message:
That _can_ be the case. Part of the operating model we need to support is the possibility of things that neutron has no clue about, where the operator does have an understanding of its existence. In other words, I want to deploy a machine that is six steps removed from me, and is not neutron integrated.

Granted, for the nova workflow this doesn't really work if neutron is not aware and does not control the far edge networking, but this does work for the Metal3/Standalone/BMaaS directly with ironic use case.

The previous bullet point is to let the operator manage IP allocation without Neutron entirely.

specs/approved/L3-based-deployment.rst.message:
Base functionality existing doesn't mean we automatically try and increase scope because of it.

We simply should not be in the business of trying to manage the machine's virtual media and configuration passing in any generally supported case outside deployment unless there is a really compelling argument. Again going to my first sentence of this comment.

To be explicitly clear, "ramdisk" functionality has largely been to support the scientific computing community as they run many environments without physical locally attached storage. Continuing that for networking management when tools like cloud-init re-parse configuration drives only if the instance-id change. Hopefully this explains why Dmitry and Myself are pushing for this to be focused on "deployment" where an image is written to the disk, and not the actual booting of the instance after that point much less the configuration for that instance.

Besides "ramdisk" functionality, what I had in mind is the scenario when ironic net-boots the instance with a config-drive partition on the local drive. The configuration buried there can't be changed without re-deployment. So I am trying to point out, that putting config-drive on boot ISO seemingly solves this.

Anyway, I stripped everything instance-related from the spec.

We have the functionality to distribute instance config via local drive partition (which is truly static), however here we have the ability to change deployed node network configuration by rebooting.

The #5 feature is thought to be limited to redfish-virtual-media boot interface only. Perhaps not overriding existing network_data.json in the config-drive would be a safer strategy.

I think in this case we'd need to add fields to the port object for ip address, netmask, routes info etc. And build out network_data.json file based on that. Populating that based on neutron port data or a full network_data.json seems doable.

I did'nt read all previous comments, but I assume operators expressed they are happy with building the network_data.json, they don't want an Ironic interface? (To me, ``openstack baremetal port set --ipaddress addr/prefix --route net/prefix,nexthop --mtu ****`` seems appealing.)

This is the running instance, and is outside the scope of deployment. The text should be removed and the idea possibly furthered in an RFE.

The instance _should_ have all of the data that is required to boot it. Ironic rebuilding the configuration drive and injecting new contents ultimately provides value to only operating systems that grok configuration drives and read the network-data.json document. The instance may be something like RHCOS with user-data is actually an ignition document and our network-data.json is ignored. Or even some special purpose OS that still has no comprehension of network booting. Or maybe there is local DHCP/SLAAC, but that is not the way to find the provisioning infrastructure.

Regardless, should trim the text down, focus the scope so we can reach a point where we can move forward.

heat/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message: removed cuz this is wrapped for _try_resource_update
if this has arguments then it needs to return the decorator function, func can't be inline here
this generally means that it is wrapped in the other methods, like update_and_save
when we are in this block, we are outside of where the "session.begin()" method has been called.   at this point, we can retry an operation, because the transaction is encompassed within this retry.

do you mean that is original behavior or changes introduced by this patch? If the former, please let's consider changing the established patterns in another patches as this one only improves wrapping around the established things.

to get a SQLAlchemy ORM Session object that meets the criteria of "session.transaction is None", you do:

   session = Session(autocommit=True)

and then you don't call begin().  All the Sessions that oslo.db pushes out currently have the autocommit=True flag set.  

the second part of the conditional, "or not context.session.autocommit", means nothing as far as what transactional state the session would be in.  since oslo.db and openstack apps are AFAIK not using sessions with autocommit=False, I dont think the second part of this conditional would ever be triggered.

so at the moment, the conditional should be successfully indicating that we are outside of the Session.begin() block.

I'm not following what you mean by "changing the established patterns".

when we are here, session.begin() has been called, we're inside the transction, we can't retry in here, because a failure rolls back the session, we would go to the top of the function, but nobody is there to call session.begin() again.  OK.

this provides the original "else" path as is. My hope was to change nothing functionally here in that case but only masking the newly added retries on disconnect as well. Would be nice here too to separate things related to wrappers and changing the established patterns with sessions etc (out of scope here)...
yes, I believe here you have retained the original functionality.

but here, I don't know what this part is doing.  

1. are we inside of a session.begin() already?  if so, then we can't do a retry.

2. are we not inside of a session.begin()?  are there functions that are doing things with the database / session that are *not* inside of a begin() block?  this is a legacy pattern that will not be possible in future versions of SQLAlchemy.   oslo.db's current enginefacade pattern when used fully also disallows it. 

3. if 2 is true, what is an example of a database operation that is raising DBDeadlock *outside* of session.begin()?   that would be the real problem here.

oslo.db and SQLAlchemy already automatically reconnect if the database was disconnected and a new transaction is beginning.   This has been in the library for many years and can be seen here: https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/master/oslo_db/sqlalchemy/engines.py#L54

SQLAlchemy now includes this functionality natively as well however oslo.db is still using its own approach (which inspired that of SQLAlchemy).

there should be no need for Heat to attempt to add extra rules that would allow a disconnected database connection to reconnect when it is about to be used in a new transaction, so I still don't know what is trying to be accomplished here.  is there a stack trace I can see of what the problem we're attempting to solve is ?

> 1. are we inside of a session.begin() already?  if so, then we can't do a retry.

that is it, right. And indeed we can't do retrying of open transactions here unless we mark it "idempotent". So I assumed here that all idempotent operations can be retried in the middle of it, after the session.begin() or whatever initiates it.

That's up to the user of the decorator how to mark things safe for retrying on disconnect.

that is an extension to the default "else" path, but added a capability of retrying on disconnects only (not on deadlocks as the transaction is open yet but considered safe to retry on disconnects - aka idempotent here)
actually I was tryin to understand the retry_on_disconnect=True feature of oslo.db and find a use of it here. It seems I understood it wrong :)
TBD: this needs an extra unit test to verify that it omits deadlocks but retries on disconnects.

This would help prevent any future issues that arise if the docker-in-docker situation was not 'detected' properly as the exec method would *always* run if there was an error with the old method.

The method to check for docker based on /proc/self/cgroup is a well documented way to decide if a process is running running in a container or not. Please see:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/23513045/how-to-check-if-a-process-is-running-inside-docker-container

If we try to run the first method blindly without first assessing the environment, we will not be able to assess if a issue is due to an actual issue in a vm based pipeline or because we are running in a container.
I think it is better to differentiate between the 2 cases and treat them differently.
Do you have any concern that this method might not capture if a process runs in a container?
Why are we running grep here instead of just storing the result into the RESULT variable? Is there inconsistent output preventing that?

Since we are running curl in a docker exec terminal depending on the terminal setting we might receive some garbage in addition to the "HTTP:/1.1 200 OK". I did this to ignore the garbage and only look for what I was searching for, as a safer way to assess success.
because grep return some garbage in addition to the HTTP/1.1 200 OK, due to terminal setting with exec is run. This way we ignore other garbage that is also captured.
should this also have -e so it fails fast if one of the docker commands fails?
No. this should not have -e, because below we need to continue the validation test even if some calls fail.

sushy_tools/emulator/resources/chassis/b.message: I agree with Dmitry, plus changing the overall meaning of a positional argument seems wrong without a major rev. (Yes, 0.x series at present, but still.)

I do not quite see why...

If A is calling B.f(C) and that is not a violation of layers, is B calling C.f()  a violation of layers?

To me, it's all about interfaces agreement. For example, if `C` is agreed upon being a file object, it's totally common for the consumer (B) to access internals of C e.g. C.write.

Alternatively, we could pass the consumer all the necessary internals e.g. B(C.read, C.write, C.close), which is obviously a way to go as well. It's probably the matter of balance - how many positionals is too many and the anticipation of further expansion of C surface. ;-)
Drivers calling back to the API layer seems a big violation of layers.

Well, the driver could then call back its WSGI app to find out something about the query or use the resources that are owned by WSGI app. In that light, I do not see this as outstandingly awkward.

Two args are OK for as long as it's not 3. Which is not impossible going forward.

I'm curious why this was changed to debug, which means it will generally not get logged in real deployments? It would seem useful in detecting incorrect configurations, etc..

If you changed this to debug in order to eliminate superfluous messages, is there a way to determine whether there really should be topology information before deciding to log a message, or maybe even before deciding to call this function?

I had somehow missed the two calls to this function above, which is the whole point of this patch.  Maybe the logging should be moved to the caller, only if no topology is found in either current or original.

In cases where the port is unbound, then the "current" member of the port_context object doesn't have topology information. I'd considered having the caller of this method decide whether to use the "current" vs. "original" member of the port_context, but that led to duplication of code in places, which seemed to make things a bit less readable.  It also seemed a bit wrong for the caller to determine whether or not to decide which one to pass to this method by introspecting both for topology information.

mistral/tests/unit/engine/test_direct_wo.message:
Honestly, I don't understand the idea of this test. The first thing that bothers me is that it's named after an internal method that can change any time and in general can be removed later if we are able to come up with a different solution for "join". If it was a direct test for the method "find_indirectly_affected_task" then it would be OK, I would understand that. But here you mention the name of the method and the test body, in fact, has nothing to do with it. Of course, I understand the relationship exists, but it's really not obvious at all.

Also, I don't see it's related to "join, whereas it should be because this algorigthm is not needed w/o join.

My suggestion is to rewrite the test so that it:

* Uses "join" explicitly
* Shows a situation when "join" doesn't work properly w/o a proper fix
